clean_story:
Carbon crushed. Skies glittering.

The name "diamond rain" comes from storms where diamonds form in the air and fall like hail.

Deep inside planets like Neptune or Uranus, pressure squeezes methane into soot. The soot hardens into graphite, then diamond—like charcoal turning to gemstones under a hammer.

These diamonds grow heavy and sink, melting into liquid carbon rivers near the core. Scientists recreated this in labs using lasers to crush plastic into nanodiamonds.

On Saturn, lightning might spark diamond showers too. A single storm could drop thousands of carats—enough to fill a dump truck.

Three related subjects are exoplanet atmospheres, high-pressure chemistry, and how planets store carbon.
